bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Jessie Daniel Ames, March 21, 1929

div1.p: Kean responds to Ames' inquiry about the pension bill and offers reasons why Roger Ames is not included.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Jessie Daniel Ames, March 21, 1929
div1.opener:
COPY
From Mrs Ames
THE ASSOCIATION OF MILITARY SURGEONS OF THE UNITED STATES
THE MILITARY SURGEON
Washington, D. C.
March 21, 1929
Mrs. Jessie Daniel Ames,
Georgetown, Texas.
My dear Mrs. Ames:
div1.p:
I have your letter of the 16th and can well understand your feleling that the
memory of your fine husband, Dr. Roger Post Ames, should not be forgotten in any
discussion of the conquest of yellow fever in Cuba. I know very well how devoted
and valuable were his services to us all in that gloomy year, 1900, when we were
facing an apparently hopeless fight with yellow fever in Cuba. Dr. Ames, being
expert in the diagnosis and treatment of yellow fever, was a great help to us in
those days. Besides my recognition of the value of his services, I have a strong
felling of gratitude to him for his good care of me when I suffered with an attack
of that disease. I think, however, that you have been mininformed as to the scope
of the recent legislation. I have never heard that it was the intention of Congress
that (as you say) “all of those who assisted in the yellow fever work in Cuba were
to receive recognition at the hands of the government.” In fact the beneficiaries
of the bill are limited to the members of the Board (or their widows), and the
Americans who volunteered to submit to the experiments of the Board. Not even all
of these are included, but only those who had an attack of experimental yellow
fever, or who went through what Reed called “the trying ordeal” of sleeping twenty
nights in the infected bedding. Those who offered themselves for experiment and
were bitten by infected mosquitoes, but did not have an attack of yellow fever
were not included. The Spaniards who submitted to the experiments, even though
they suffered attacks of yellow fever were not included. Even of those who were
mentioned in the report of the Secretary of War, Hon. Elihu Root, for 1902 as having
rendered distinguished service in the conquest of yellow fever, two are not men-
tioned in this legislation. In view of these facts I think you will agree with me
that it would have been impossible to have brought in the name of Dr. Ames not-
withstanding his fine work in the care of the yellow fever sick. His children will
have no reason to feel that his ommission from this Act is in any way a reflection
upon his service in Cuba which is held in grateful remembrance by his old friends
and comrades who served with him in the dark days of 1899 and 1900. I am enclosing
you a copy of the Act.

I have shown your letter and this reply to the Surgeon General of the Army and
he entirely concurs with me in what I have stated above.
With all good wishes, I am

closer.signed:
(Signed) J. R. Kean
Colonel, U.S. Army, Retired
